AUTH-001.title: Splash
assumptions: User has just launched the app for the first time or after closing it
App can check localStorage for existing auth state
Network connectivity is not required at this stage
AUTH-001.userScenario: A user opens the MedAlpha Connect app and sees a brief branded splash screen. The app checks if they're already logged in and routes them accordingly - to home if authenticated, or to login if not.
pros: Creates a professional first impression with branded visuals
Provides time for app initialization without showing loading spinners
Auto-routes returning users directly to home, reducing friction
cons: Fixed 2-second delay may feel slow for returning users
No skip option for users who want to get in faster
Animation may not render smoothly on older devices
AUTH-001.impactIfWrong: If auth check fails silently, logged-in users would be sent to login unnecessarily, causing confusion and requiring them to sign in again.

AUTH-002.title: Login
assumptions: User has an existing account or knows they need to create one
Demo mode is acceptable for prototype/stakeholder demos
SSO partners (dm, PAYBACK) have integration points ready
AUTH-002.userScenario: A returning user wants to sign in to access their appointments and prescriptions. They can use email/password, or sign in through a retail partner (dm, PAYBACK) if they came from that ecosystem.
pros: Demo credentials pre-filled reduces friction during stakeholder demos
SSO options provide faster login for partner app users
Clear path to registration for new users
Password visibility toggle improves usability
cons: Demo mode indicator may confuse real users in production
No biometric login option (Face ID, fingerprint)
Forgot password is a placeholder - no actual flow implemented
AUTH-002.impactIfWrong: If SSO integration fails, partner users cannot access the app through their preferred login method, breaking the retail partner value proposition.

REG-001.title: Create Account
assumptions: User is new and doesn't have an existing account
User has a valid email address they can access
Password requirements (8+ chars, uppercase, number) are acceptable
REG-001.userScenario: A new user wants to create an account to book appointments or redeem prescriptions. They start by providing their email and creating a secure password that meets the displayed requirements.
pros: Live password validation gives immediate feedback on requirements
Step indicator (1 of 5) sets clear expectations for registration length
Password confirmation prevents typos that would lock users out
Show/hide password toggle helps users verify what they typed
cons: 5-step registration may feel long compared to social login
No social sign-up option (Google, Apple) for faster onboarding
Password requirements may frustrate users with simple passwords
REG-001.impactIfWrong: If validation is too strict or unclear, users may abandon registration. If too lenient, accounts become vulnerable to unauthorized access.

REG-002.title: Verify Email
assumptions: User has access to the email address they provided
Email verification code is delivered within 60 seconds
6-digit codes are sufficient security for email verification
REG-002.userScenario: After creating an account, the user receives a 6-digit verification code via email. They enter this code to prove they own the email address before continuing with profile setup.
pros: Countdown timer sets clear expectation for when resend becomes available
Large input field with tracking makes code entry easy
Option to use different email if wrong address was entered
Demo mode accepts any 6-digit code for testing
cons: Email delivery delays could cause users to abandon registration
No fallback if user cannot access email (e.g., typo in address)
Single verification method - no backup SMS option
REG-002.impactIfWrong: If verification emails are delayed or filtered as spam, users get stuck and cannot complete registration, leading to abandonment at a critical funnel point.

REG-003.title: Personal Info
assumptions: User has verified their email in the previous step
User is willing to provide personal details for healthcare services
German phone numbers (+49) are the primary user base
Address is needed for prescription delivery or appointment context
REG-003.userScenario: The user provides their personal information including name, date of birth, phone number, and address. This data is required for booking appointments and receiving prescription deliveries.
pros: Pre-set +49 country code removes friction for German users
Inline explanation of why phone number is needed builds trust
Progress indicator (Step 2 of 5) shows advancement through flow
All fields required ensures complete profile for healthcare use
cons: Asking for full address upfront may feel intrusive to some users
No address autocomplete - manual entry is error-prone
Date picker UX varies by device and may be awkward on mobile
REG-003.impactIfWrong: Incomplete or incorrect personal info could prevent appointment check-in or prescription delivery. Phone number errors would block SMS verification in prescription flows.

REG-004.title: Insurance Type
assumptions: User knows whether they have public (GKV) or private (PKV) insurance
User understands the difference affects how they redeem prescriptions
Most users in Germany are GKV (roughly 90% of population)
REG-004.userScenario: The user selects their insurance type - GKV (public) or PKV (private). This determines the prescription redemption flow they'll use later: NFC card scan for GKV, or GesundheitsID app login for PKV.
pros: Clear visual distinction between GKV and PKV with color coding
Bullet points explain practical differences (copay vs reimbursement)
Help section with card image assists users who are unsure
Examples of real insurers (TK, AOK, Allianz) aid recognition
cons: Users with both GKV and PKV coverage may be confused about which to choose
Help section requires extra tap - not immediately visible
No option for users without German health insurance
REG-004.impactIfWrong: Wrong insurance type selection leads to failed prescription redemption later. GKV users sent to PKV flow won't have GesundheitsID, and vice versa for NFC card.

REG-005.title: GKV Details
assumptions: User selected GKV (public insurance) in the previous step
User has their Gesundheitskarte (health card) accessible
User is willing to acknowledge the €5-10 copay per medication
REG-005.userScenario: A GKV-insured user enters their insurance provider and member number. They review how the NFC prescription flow works (scan card, enter CAN, SMS verify, pay copay) and acknowledge the copay requirement.
pros: Dropdown of common insurers (TK, AOK, Barmer) speeds selection
4-step explanation prepares users for the NFC flow they'll encounter later
Copay acknowledgment checkbox prevents surprise at checkout
Help icon on insurance number field provides guidance
cons: Users may not have their card handy to look up the insurance number
Limited insurer list - smaller insurers may not appear
No validation that insurance number format is correct
REG-005.impactIfWrong: Incorrect insurance details could cause prescription retrieval to fail when NFC scanning. Users unaware of copay may abandon at payment step.

REG-006.title: PKV Details
assumptions: User selected PKV (private insurance) in the previous step
User may or may not have GesundheitsID set up with their insurer
PKV users understand they pay upfront and get reimbursed later
REG-006.userScenario: A PKV-insured user selects their private insurer and reviews the prerequisites for digital prescription redemption: having a KVNR, the insurer's app with GesundheitsID, and completed online check-in.
pros: Checklist format makes prerequisites clear before user commits
4-step flow explanation sets correct expectations for reimbursement process
Reassurance that local pharmacies remain an option if not ready
Continue button works even without all checkboxes - low friction
cons: Three prerequisite checkboxes may feel overwhelming for new users
KVNR, GesundheitsID, Online Check-in are unfamiliar terms for many
External link to learn more takes users out of registration flow
REG-006.impactIfWrong: Users who skip prerequisites will fail when attempting prescription redemption via GesundheitsID, causing frustration. They'll need to fall back to offline pharmacy.

REG-007.title: Registration Complete
assumptions: User has completed all previous registration steps
Registration data has been saved successfully to local storage
User is now authenticated and can access main app features
REG-007.userScenario: The user sees a success confirmation after completing registration. They're shown a summary of their account details and insurance type, with next steps guidance and clear CTAs to explore the app or book an appointment.
pros: Celebratory checkmark animation creates positive emotional moment
User card summary confirms details were saved correctly
Next steps differ by insurance type (GKV: have card ready, PKV: set up GesundheitsID)
Two CTAs give user choice: explore freely or take immediate action
cons: No option to edit details if user notices an error in the summary
User may not read next steps and be unprepared for prescription flow later
Success animation may not render for users with reduced motion preferences
REG-007.impactIfWrong: If data fails to save, user believes they're registered but has no account. If success shows despite errors, user will encounter issues later in the app.

HOME-001.title: Home Dashboard
assumptions: User is logged in with a completed profile (registration or SSO)
LocalStorage contains valid user profile and appointment data
User understands German healthcare context and has insurance set up
Network connectivity is not required for displaying cached local data
HOME-001.userScenario: A returning user opens the app to check their upcoming appointments or start a new healthcare task. They see personalized content including their next scheduled visit, promotional offers, and quick access to book appointments—the app's primary value proposition. The home screen serves as the hub from which all healthcare journeys begin.
pros: Prominent 'Book Appointment' CTA directly addresses the primary user job-to-be-done
Upcoming appointment widget surfaces time-sensitive info without requiring navigation
Auto-rotating promo carousel enables dynamic content updates without code changes
Loading skeleton provides realistic feedback during data fetch, building trust
Empty state with CTA guides new users toward their first meaningful action
cons: Promo carousel content is hardcoded—not yet connected to a real CMS
No personalized greeting (e.g., 'Good morning, Maria') despite having user data
Recent activity section shows static placeholder, not actual user history
Notification bell is visual only—no functional notification system behind it
HOME-001.impactIfWrong: If the home screen fails to load user data or displays stale appointment info, users may miss scheduled visits or lose trust in the app as their reliable healthcare companion.

BKG-001.title: Booking Type
assumptions: User wants to schedule a healthcare appointment and has a completed profile
User understands the difference between in-person visits and telemedicine
Teleclinic partnership is active and can handle video consultation handoff
User has a device capable of video calls if choosing telemedicine option
BKG-001.userScenario: A user navigates from the home screen to book an appointment. They're presented with two clear paths: visit a clinic in-person for hands-on care, or connect with a doctor via video call through Teleclinic for convenience. The choice depends on their medical need and schedule flexibility.
pros: Binary choice reduces cognitive load—users don't face a complex decision tree
Clear visual distinction with icons (building vs video) aids quick comprehension
Teleclinic badge signals trusted partnership for telemedicine
Touch feedback (scale animation) confirms interaction on mobile
cons: No guidance on which option is better for specific symptoms or conditions
Video option immediately exits to Teleclinic—no native telemedicine flow
Users may not know their condition requires in-person examination
BKG-001.impactIfWrong: If users choose video for conditions requiring physical examination, they waste time and may delay necessary care. If Teleclinic handoff fails, users have no fallback telemedicine option.

BKG-002.title: Specialty Select
assumptions: User knows what type of medical specialty they need (or has a rough idea)
Six displayed specialties cover the most common appointment types
Search functionality will help users find specialties not shown in the grid
Specialty selection determines which doctors appear in subsequent steps
BKG-002.userScenario: A user who selected in-person booking needs to specify what kind of doctor they want to see. They scan a visual grid of common specialties (GP, Dermatology, Cardiology, etc.) or use search to find something specific. This narrows down the doctor pool for the next steps.
pros: Visual grid with icons makes specialty recognition faster than a text list
Color-coded icons create visual distinction between specialties
Search bar accommodates users who know exactly what they need
Staggered animation draws attention to available options
cons: Only 6 specialties shown—users may not find their needed specialty without searching
Search is UI-only (placeholder)—not connected to a real specialty database
No description of what each specialty treats, which may confuse users
No 'I don't know' option for users unsure of which specialist they need
BKG-002.impactIfWrong: Users who select the wrong specialty will see irrelevant doctors, potentially booking with someone who can't address their condition. This wastes time and may require rebooking.

BKG-003.title: Location Select
assumptions: User has granted location permissions or is comfortable with Berlin-area defaults
Nearby clinics have availability for the selected specialty
Distance and ratings are reliable decision factors for users
Map visual provides helpful spatial context even without full interactivity
BKG-003.userScenario: After selecting a specialty, the user chooses which clinic to visit. They see a map placeholder showing their approximate location and a list of nearby clinics sorted by distance. Ratings and review counts help them pick a reputable location convenient to their commute.
pros: Distance badges give users immediate travel context without calculations
Rating and review count builds trust in clinic quality
Loading skeleton provides feedback while 'searching' for clinics
Map placeholder sets visual expectation for location-based selection
cons: Map is not interactive—users cannot pan/zoom or tap pins
Clinic list is hardcoded, not filtered by actual specialty availability
No option to search by address or filter by specific criteria (parking, accessibility)
Distance calculation is static, not based on real user location
BKG-003.impactIfWrong: If displayed clinics don't actually have the selected specialty or availability, users will hit a dead end when trying to book. Inaccurate distances could lead to missed appointments due to travel time miscalculation.

BKG-004.title: Doctor Select
assumptions: User values being able to choose their specific doctor rather than being assigned one
Filters (all, available today, top-rated) cover the main decision criteria
Doctor ratings and next availability are accurate and up-to-date
User has flexibility in timing and can accommodate different availability windows
BKG-004.userScenario: A user who has selected a clinic now picks their preferred doctor. They browse a list showing doctor names, specialties, ratings, and next available slot. Quick filters let them narrow down to doctors available today or those with the highest ratings if they're willing to wait.
pros: Filter chips enable quick narrowing without complex form interactions
'Next available' preview helps users gauge how soon they can be seen
Rating badges provide social proof for quality assurance
Empty state guides users when no doctors match the selected filter
cons: No doctor photos—placeholder circles reduce personal connection
Cannot filter by gender, language, or specific expertise areas
Doctor list is from constants, not tied to actual clinic availability
No way to view doctor profiles or patient reviews before selecting
BKG-004.impactIfWrong: If 'Next available' times are inaccurate, users may select a doctor expecting immediate availability only to find different times on the calendar. If ratings don't reflect actual quality, users may have poor experiences.

BKG-005.title: Calendar
assumptions: User has flexibility to book within the available time slots shown
Time slot availability varies by day (weekdays vs weekends, busy days)
Past dates should be disabled to prevent invalid bookings
User device displays dates correctly in their locale
BKG-005.userScenario: The user picks their preferred appointment date and time. They tap a date on the calendar to reveal available time slots, which vary based on clinic hours (closed Sundays, limited Saturday hours, busier Monday/Wednesday). Once both date and time are selected, they can proceed to review.
pros: Calendar widget provides familiar date-picking interaction
Time slots dynamically update based on selected date, showing realistic availability
Clear visual states for today, selected date, and disabled past dates
Sticky continue button is always accessible without scrolling
cons: No indication of which dates have availability before tapping
Time slots are algorithmically generated, not from real scheduling system
Cannot book multiple consecutive slots for longer appointments
No timezone handling—assumes user is in the clinic's timezone
BKG-005.impactIfWrong: If shown time slots don't match actual availability, the booking will fail at confirmation or require rebooking. Users in different timezones could book at unexpected local times.

BKG-006.title: Review Booking
assumptions: User has completed all prior steps (doctor, location, date/time selection)
Booking draft data persists in localStorage across navigation
User wants a final review before committing to the appointment
Date and time formatting respects user's locale preferences
BKG-006.userScenario: Before finalizing, the user reviews all booking details: selected doctor, clinic location, date, and time. Each section has an edit link allowing them to go back and change that specific item without restarting the entire flow. The confirm button creates the appointment.
pros: Consolidated summary prevents errors from booking the wrong details
Inline edit links allow targeted corrections without losing other selections
Localized date/time display matches user's language preference
Loading state on confirm button prevents double-submission
cons: Cannot add notes or reason for visit at this stage
No cost estimate or insurance verification before confirming
Address shown is static placeholder, not the actual clinic address
No cancellation policy or rescheduling information displayed
BKG-006.impactIfWrong: If displayed details don't match what was actually selected, user may confirm a wrong appointment. If the appointment fails to save, user believes they're booked but no record exists.

BKG-007.title: Booking Success
assumptions: Appointment was successfully saved to localStorage before showing this screen
User benefits from visual confirmation that their action completed
Calendar integration is a valued feature for appointment management
Session storage correctly passes the appointment ID from the previous step
BKG-007.userScenario: After confirming, the user sees a celebratory success screen with a green checkmark animation. A summary card shows doctor name, date/time, and location. They can add the appointment to their device calendar or tap 'Done' to return home.
pros: Animated checkmark creates positive emotional reinforcement
Summary card provides one last verification of booking details
Add to Calendar button helps users not forget their appointment
Clean, focused layout without distractions celebrates the completion
cons: Add to Calendar is UI-only—no actual calendar integration implemented
No confirmation email or SMS—relies solely on in-app storage
If user navigates away before seeing this, they may not realize booking succeeded
No option to book another appointment or share the details
BKG-007.impactIfWrong: If this screen shows despite a failed save, user believes they have an appointment that doesn't exist. If they rely on 'Add to Calendar' that doesn't work, they may miss the appointment.

BKG-008.title: Smart Match Processing
assumptions: Smart Match is an AI/algorithm-powered service that finds optimal appointments
Users are willing to wait 10-30 seconds for automated matching
70% of requests can be fulfilled immediately, 30% require refinement
Retry attempts (from refinement) should always succeed to avoid frustration loops
BKG-008.userScenario: Instead of manually selecting every booking detail, the user lets Smart Match find them an optimal appointment. This screen shows a progress animation while the system 'processes' the request—verifying info, finding availability, and confirming. Users can cancel if they prefer manual booking.
pros: Step-by-step progress indicators reduce perceived wait time
Animated progress bar provides continuous feedback during processing
Cancel button gives users an escape hatch if they change their mind
Retry logic ensures second attempts succeed, preventing infinite loops
cons: Processing is simulated—no real backend matching is happening
Random success/failure (70/30 split) may frustrate users who hit refinement
No visibility into what 'Smart Match' is actually doing or considering
2.5-second fixed delay doesn't adapt to network conditions
BKG-008.impactIfWrong: If processing appears stuck or takes too long, users may abandon and lose trust in Smart Match. If the random failure rate is too high, users will avoid this feature entirely.

BKG-009.title: Smart Match Refinement
assumptions: User's initial preferences couldn't be fully matched (time, specialty, or location)
Offering alternatives is better than simply failing the request
Users are flexible enough to accept one of the suggested alternatives
Three options per scenario provides sufficient choice without overwhelming
BKG-009.userScenario: When Smart Match can't find an exact match, the user sees this refinement screen. It explains what went wrong (unavailable time, suggests alternative specialist, or nearby clinic) and offers three alternatives. The user picks one, and the system retries—this time guaranteed to succeed.
pros: Clear explanation of why refinement is needed (not just 'error')
Scenario-specific options (time slots, specialties, or locations) feel personalized
Selection cards with visual feedback make choosing easy
Cancel option respects users who prefer to book manually instead
cons: Random scenario selection doesn't relate to actual user preferences
Options are hardcoded, not based on real availability data
Amber warning styling may feel more alarming than necessary
No option to provide custom preferences beyond the three choices
BKG-009.impactIfWrong: If alternatives don't actually match user needs, they're forced into an unwanted appointment or must cancel. If the retry fails again, users lose trust in the entire Smart Match system.

BKG-010.title: Smart Match Success
assumptions: Smart Match has successfully found and booked an appointment
Generated appointment is 3-5 days in the future to feel realistic
User wants to see full booking details immediately after success
Auto-redirect to appointments list helps users find their booking
BKG-010.userScenario: After Smart Match successfully processes a booking, the user sees a purple-branded success screen with a detailed confirmation card. It shows the matched doctor, clinic, date, and time. The screen auto-redirects to the appointments list after 3 seconds, or users can tap to go immediately.
pros: Distinct purple branding differentiates Smart Match from manual booking success
'Smart Match' and 'Confirmed' badges reinforce the feature that was used
Detailed card provides all essential booking information at a glance
Auto-redirect ensures users land where they can manage their appointments
cons: Doctor and clinic are hardcoded, not reflecting user's original preferences
3-second auto-redirect may feel rushed for users still reading details
No option to add to calendar like the manual booking success screen
Gradient background may not render well on all devices
BKG-010.impactIfWrong: If the shown details don't match the actual saved appointment, users will be confused when they see different info in their appointments list. If auto-redirect happens too fast, users may miss important details.

RX-001.title: Prescriptions List
assumptions: User has active e-prescriptions stored in the Telematik Infrastruktur (TI)
Insurance type (GKV/PKV) is already set in the user's profile
Prescriptions are valid for 28 days from issue date
GKV users understand the copay (Zuzahlung) concept of €5-10 per medication
RX-001.userScenario: A user who has received e-prescriptions from their doctor visits this screen to view and select which medications to redeem. GKV users see fixed copay amounts while PKV users see full prices with reimbursement notes. The user can toggle an exemption checkbox if they have a Befreiungsausweis.
pros: Clear insurance-specific pricing (copay vs full price) reduces confusion at checkout
Multi-select with checkboxes lets users redeem multiple prescriptions in one order
Tab filter (Active/Redeemed) helps users track prescription status over time
Copay exemption toggle is prominently placed for users who qualify
cons: Prescription data is hardcoded—not connected to real TI system
No indication of which prescriptions were issued together by the same doctor
Expiry warning is not prominent—users might miss approaching deadlines
No search or filter by medication name for users with many prescriptions
RX-001.impactIfWrong: If prescription data doesn't sync with the TI, users may attempt to redeem already-filled prescriptions or miss active ones. Wrong copay calculations would cause payment surprises at checkout.

RX-002.title: Redeem Start
assumptions: User wants to redeem a new prescription (not already loaded in the app)
User understands the difference between online delivery and local pickup
Insurance type determines the authentication flow (NFC for GKV, GesundheitsID for PKV)
Apo Group partnership is active and can fulfill online orders
RX-002.userScenario: A user taps the '+' FAB from the prescriptions screen to start redeeming a new prescription. They choose between online pharmacy (delivery) or finding a local pharmacy (pickup). The screen adapts its guidance based on insurance type—GKV users will scan their card, PKV users will authenticate via their insurer's app.
pros: Binary choice (online vs local) is simple and covers the main use cases
Insurance badge toggle allows testing both flows without re-registering
Info banner explains the authentication method before user commits
Partnership badge (Apo Group) signals trusted fulfillment partner
cons: Insurance toggle is a prototype feature—real users can't switch insurance types
No price comparison between online and local pharmacy options
Local pharmacy option exits to a separate flow with no return path
No indication of delivery timeframes to help users choose
RX-002.impactIfWrong: If users don't understand which authentication they need, they'll hit blockers in the next steps. If Apo Group partnership fails, online pharmacy becomes unusable.

RX-003.title: NFC Intro (GKV)
assumptions: User has their Gesundheitskarte (eGK) physically present
User's phone has NFC capability and it's enabled in settings
The 6-digit CAN (Card Access Number) is printed on the card front
User understands this is a security step to access their prescriptions
RX-003.userScenario: A GKV-insured user prepares to scan their health card using NFC. The screen guides them through the prerequisites: locating their card, finding the CAN, and positioning for the scan. They enter the 6-digit CAN and tap 'Start Scanning' to initiate the NFC read.
pros: Step-by-step instructions reduce confusion about the NFC process
Visual animation (floating card, pulse effect) creates clear mental model
CAN input validation ensures 6 digits before enabling the scan button
Help link for 'Where is my CAN?' assists first-time users
cons: No detection of whether device actually supports NFC before starting
CAN entry is manual—no option to scan it from the card visually
Help link is placeholder only—no actual help content
No guidance for users with older eGK cards that may have different CAN locations
RX-003.impactIfWrong: Wrong CAN entry will cause NFC authentication to fail. Users without NFC-capable phones will be blocked with no alternative path. If card positioning guidance is unclear, repeated scan failures frustrate users.

RX-004.title: NFC Scan
assumptions: User has their Gesundheitskarte positioned against the phone's NFC reader
NFC communication is stable and uninterrupted during the 4-second scan
Phone's NFC hardware can successfully read eGK cards
User will hold the card still despite the visual prompt to do so
RX-004.userScenario: The user holds their health card against their phone while the app communicates with it via NFC. A dark, focused UI with animated pulse effects creates a 'scanning in progress' atmosphere. Haptic feedback (if supported) confirms the scan is active. After ~4 seconds, the user is routed to SMS verification.
pros: Full-screen dark mode UI reduces distractions and creates focus
Animated pulse and phone vibration provide multi-sensory feedback
Clear 'Hold your card still' instruction prevents premature movement
Cancel button provides escape hatch if user changes their mind
cons: NFC scan is simulated with fixed 4-second timer—no real card reading
No error handling if NFC fails or card is removed prematurely
20-second estimate may not match actual scan times in production
No positioning guidance showing where exactly to place the card on the phone
RX-004.impactIfWrong: If NFC fails silently, users wait indefinitely with no feedback. If scan times vary wildly from the estimate, users may assume failure and retry unnecessarily. Lack of card positioning guidance causes repeated scan failures.

RX-005.title: GKV SMS Verify
assumptions: User's phone number on file with their insurance is correct and accessible
SMS delivery is reliable and arrives within the 45-second countdown
6-digit verification codes provide adequate security for prescription access
User has the same phone that will receive the SMS
RX-005.userScenario: After NFC card scan, the user receives an SMS with a 6-digit verification code to their registered phone number. They enter this code to prove they control the phone associated with their insurance record. This two-factor authentication protects against unauthorized prescription access.
pros: Masked phone number (+49 *** ***78) shows enough digits to confirm it's theirs
Large centered input field with tracking makes code entry easy on mobile
Countdown timer sets clear expectation for when resend becomes available
Link to check profile helps users whose phone number may be outdated
cons: SMS delivery delays could exceed the 45-second expectation
No fallback if user doesn't have access to the registered phone
Demo mode accepts any 6-digit code—not representative of real security
Phone number cannot be changed from this screen—must exit flow
RX-005.impactIfWrong: If SMS is delayed or lost, users are blocked from accessing prescriptions. Wrong phone number on file means SMS goes to wrong device. If verification bypass exists in production, prescription data could be compromised.

RX-006.title: PKV Auth
assumptions: User has a KVNR (Krankenversichertennummer) from their private insurer
User's PKV app has GesundheitsID already configured and activated
User has completed Online Check-in at their doctor to enable e-prescriptions
OAuth-style handoff to insurer apps is technically feasible
RX-006.userScenario: A PKV-insured user begins the prescription retrieval process. Before proceeding, they see a checklist of prerequisites (KVNR, GesundheitsID, Online Check-in) to verify they're set up correctly. Users who aren't ready can learn how to set up, while prepared users continue to select their insurer.
pros: Checklist format clearly shows what's needed before user commits
Shield icon with 'SECURE' badge builds trust in the authentication process
'Learn how to set up' link guides unprepared users to resources
Validates prerequisites before wasting user time on authentication
cons: Technical terms (KVNR, GesundheitsID, Online Check-in) may confuse users
Checklist items are static—doesn't actually verify user has completed them
Learn more link is placeholder—no actual setup guidance provided
No indicator of which insurer apps support GesundheitsID
RX-006.impactIfWrong: Users who skip prerequisites will fail at insurer authentication. If terminology is unclear, users may think they're prepared when they're not. False confidence leads to frustrating failure later in the flow.

RX-007.title: PKV Insurer Select
assumptions: User knows which private insurance company they're enrolled with
Top 5 displayed insurers cover the majority of PKV users
Each insurer has a functioning GesundheitsID-compatible mobile app
App-to-app redirect (deep linking) works reliably on user's device
RX-007.userScenario: A PKV user selects their insurance company from a searchable list. The five most common private insurers are shown initially (Allianz, DKV, HUK-COBURG, Debeka, AXA), with search for finding others. Selecting an insurer initiates the OAuth-style handoff to that insurer's app.
pros: Search filter helps users find insurers not in the top 5
Two-letter logo placeholders provide visual variety in the list
Explanation text sets expectation for app redirect
'Show all insurers' link suggests comprehensive coverage
cons: Only 5 insurers shown—smaller providers require search
Logo placeholders are generic—not actual insurer branding
'Show all insurers' is non-functional placeholder
No indication of which insurers actually support GesundheitsID yet
RX-007.impactIfWrong: If user's insurer isn't listed or searchable, they cannot proceed. If app redirect fails, user is stuck between apps. Selecting an insurer without GesundheitsID support leads to the error screen.

RX-008.title: PKV Redirect
assumptions: User's insurer app is installed on their device
Deep link will successfully open the insurer's app
User will complete authentication in the insurer app and return
OAuth callback will bring user back to this app with valid tokens
RX-008.userScenario: An interstitial loading screen appears while the app prepares to hand off to the user's PKV insurer app. The user sees their insurer's name and a loading spinner. After authentication in the insurer app, they return here and are redirected to the prescription list.
pros: Clear messaging that user will leave and return sets expectations
Insurer name dynamically shown confirms correct selection
Cancel button allows backing out before app switch
2.5-second delay provides buffer for app transition
cons: Redirect is simulated—no actual insurer app integration
If insurer app isn't installed, no error handling or app store link
No timeout handling if user doesn't return from insurer app
Logo placeholder doesn't match actual insurer branding
RX-008.impactIfWrong: If deep link fails, user is stuck on this screen with no feedback. If user doesn't have the insurer app installed, redirect fails silently. Long delays in the insurer app may cause timeout issues.

RX-009.title: PKV Error
assumptions: GesundheitsID authentication failed due to incomplete setup
User can resolve the issue by configuring their insurer's app
Local pharmacy remains a viable alternative for prescription redemption
User understands why authentication failed to prevent repeat failures
RX-009.userScenario: When GesundheitsID authentication fails—typically because the user hasn't activated it in their insurer's app—this error screen explains the problem. It offers a button to open their PKV app for setup, a retry option, and a fallback path to use a local pharmacy instead.
pros: Clear explanation of why authentication failed (GesundheitsID not set up)
Direct button to open PKV app guides user toward resolution
Local pharmacy fallback ensures user isn't completely blocked
Try again option supports users who resolved the issue quickly
cons: Generic error message doesn't distinguish between different failure types
'Open PKV App' button is non-functional placeholder
No specific guidance on how to set up GesundheitsID in different insurer apps
Error screen is only reachable via direct URL—not from actual auth failure
RX-009.impactIfWrong: If error messaging is unclear, users won't know how to resolve the issue. If fallback options aren't prominent, frustrated users may abandon the app entirely.

RX-010.title: Prescription Detail
assumptions: User wants to view full details of a specific prescription
Prescription data includes medication name, dosage, quantity, and prescriber info
Active prescriptions can be redeemed; delivered prescriptions can be reordered
Query params distinguish between active, delivered, and picked-up states
RX-010.userScenario: A user taps a prescription card to view full details. For active prescriptions, they see medication info, dosage instructions, prescribing doctor, and validity dates with a 'Redeem' CTA. For fulfilled prescriptions, they see delivery/pickup status with options to download receipt or reorder.
pros: Same component handles multiple states (active, delivered, picked up) consistently
Clear status badges distinguish between prescription states
Detailed info (dosage, quantity, prescriber) helps users verify correct medication
Reorder button enables convenient refills for recurring medications
cons: Prescription data is hardcoded—same medication shown regardless of which card was tapped
Reorder and receipt download buttons are non-functional placeholders
No medication interaction warnings or side effect information
Status states are controlled via URL params, not actual prescription state
RX-010.impactIfWrong: If prescription details don't match what user selected, they may redeem the wrong medication. Missing dosage info could lead to medication errors. Non-functional buttons damage trust.

RX-011.title: Prescription List Select
assumptions: User has authenticated via NFC (GKV) or GesundheitsID (PKV)
Multiple prescriptions may be available from the same doctor visit
Insurance type affects pricing display (copay vs full price)
Users may have copay exemption status (Befreiungsausweis) stored
RX-011.userScenario: After successful authentication, the user sees all retrieved prescriptions with checkboxes for multi-select. GKV users see copay amounts (€5 per medication) with an exemption toggle. PKV users see full prices with reimbursement notes. The total is calculated dynamically as selections change.
pros: Success banner confirms prescriptions were successfully retrieved
Multi-select enables ordering multiple medications in one transaction
Dynamic total updates as user toggles selections
Copay exemption checkbox is contextual—only shown to GKV users
cons: Prescription list is hardcoded, not dynamically retrieved from TI
No indication if prescriptions are for the same condition or unrelated
Redeemed tab is empty—no historical data to display
Loading state uses artificial delay, not actual data fetch
RX-011.impactIfWrong: If the wrong prescriptions are shown, users might order incorrect medications. Wrong copay calculations could cause payment disputes. Missing prescriptions would require users to call their doctor.

RX-012.title: Pharmacy Confirm
assumptions: User has selected online pharmacy (Apo Group) as their fulfillment option
User understands their prescription data will be shared with the pharmacy partner
Standard delivery (1-2 business days) meets user's timing needs
User is willing to accept terms and authorize data transfer
RX-012.userScenario: Before placing the order, the user confirms they want Apo Group to fulfill their prescription. They see partner branding, delivery estimates (1-2 days, free shipping), and must accept terms authorizing prescription data transfer. This is a consent gate before finalizing the order.
pros: Partner card clearly identifies who will fulfill the prescription
Free shipping message removes potential cost concerns
Delivery estimate sets timing expectations (1-2 business days)
Checkbox consent ensures explicit authorization for data sharing
cons: No alternative pharmacy options presented—Apo Group is the only choice
Terms text is brief—doesn't link to full terms and conditions
Delivery estimate is generic—doesn't account for weekends or holidays
No mention of what happens if medication is out of stock
RX-012.impactIfWrong: If users don't realize their prescription data is shared, they may feel privacy was violated. Inaccurate delivery estimates cause frustration when packages are late.

RX-013.title: Order Review
assumptions: User has confirmed pharmacy partner and wants to finalize the order
Delivery address is correct and on file from registration
Insurance type determines payment structure (copay vs full price with reimbursement)
E-Rezept discount or Privatrezept-Bonus is automatically applied
RX-013.userScenario: A final review screen shows delivery address, order summary with pricing, and applicable discounts. GKV users see insurance coverage breakdown and pay only the discounted copay (€2.50 after e-Rezept discount). PKV users see full price with reimbursement info and earn bonus credits. Final terms acceptance precedes payment.
pros: Insurance-specific pricing breakdowns explain what user pays and why
E-Rezept-Rabatt incentivizes digital prescription redemption
PKV reimbursement info section explains the claim process
Edit button on address allows last-minute corrections
cons: Delivery address is hardcoded placeholder, not user's actual address
Edit address button is non-functional
Terms checkbox state doesn't gate the payment button
No payment method selection—assumes default payment on file
RX-013.impactIfWrong: Wrong delivery address means medication goes to wrong location. Incorrect pricing calculations damage trust and may cause payment failures. Missing terms acceptance could create legal issues.

RX-014.title: Order Success
assumptions: Payment was successfully processed and order was submitted
Order number was generated and can be used for tracking
Delivery estimate is accurate based on shipping carrier SLAs
PKV users understand they need the Kostenbeleg for reimbursement
RX-014.userScenario: After successful payment, the user sees a celebratory confirmation with animated checkmark. The order card shows order number and estimated delivery window. PKV users see additional info about the reimbursement receipt (Kostenbeleg) that will be available after delivery. Users can track the order or return home.
pros: Animated success checkmark creates positive emotional reinforcement
Order number and delivery estimate provide actionable information
PKV-specific Kostenbeleg section prepares users for reimbursement process
Preview Receipt link lets PKV users see what the document will contain
cons: Track Order button is non-functional placeholder
No email/SMS confirmation mentioned—relies solely on in-app record
Delivery estimate is hardcoded, not calculated from actual shipping data
No option to modify or cancel the order if user notices an error
RX-014.impactIfWrong: If order confirmation shows despite failed submission, user believes medication is coming when it isn't. Missing or inaccurate tracking causes anxiety about delivery status.

RX-015.title: Prescription Receipt
assumptions: Order has been delivered and Kostenbeleg is now available
PKV user needs this document to claim reimbursement from their insurer
Receipt contains all information required for insurance claim
User has storage/email access to save or send the document
RX-015.userScenario: A PKV user accesses their reimbursement receipt (Kostenbeleg) after delivery to submit to their insurer. The screen shows the order details and PDF document info with options to download, send directly to their PKV app, or email to themselves. Next steps guidance explains the reimbursement process.
pros: Multiple sharing options (download, send to app, email) cover different workflows
File info (name, size) confirms the document is ready
Next steps guidance reduces confusion about what to do with the receipt
Clear purple theming connects to PKV-specific features throughout the app
cons: All action buttons are non-functional placeholders
'Send to PKV App' would require integration with each insurer's app
No preview of the PDF content before downloading
Back navigation goes to /history which may not exist in prototype
RX-015.impactIfWrong: If receipt is missing or incomplete, PKV users cannot get reimbursed. Failed document delivery means users must contact support. Wrong amounts on receipt would result in incorrect reimbursement.

TH-001.title: Schedule Type
assumptions: User has selected 'Video Consultation' from the booking type screen
Teleclinic partner integration provides the actual video call infrastructure
On-demand telehealth is available with ~15 minute wait times
User can also schedule video calls for specific future time slots
TH-001.userScenario: A user who needs remote medical care chooses between seeing a doctor immediately (next available) or scheduling for a specific time. Users with acute but non-emergency issues typically choose 'Next Available' to minimize wait, while those with stable conditions may prefer scheduling around their work or personal calendar.
pros: Clear two-option choice prevents decision paralysis
Wait time estimate sets realistic expectations upfront
Teleclinic badge signals legitimate partner infrastructure
Reuses existing calendar flow for scheduled appointments
cons: ~15 minute estimate is hardcoded—not pulled from real queue data
No indication of doctor specialty or availability for specific conditions
Pick a Time reuses booking calendar which may not match Teleclinic's actual schedule
TH-001.impactIfWrong: If wait time estimates are inaccurate, users may abandon mid-wait or miss their turn. If scheduled times don't match Teleclinic's availability, users could book phantom appointments.

TH-002.title: Symptoms Intro (1/3)
assumptions: User can identify their symptoms from a limited category list
Multi-select is appropriate because users often have overlapping symptoms
The 6 categories cover the most common telehealth use cases
Symptom data will be stored in booking draft for review screen
TH-002.userScenario: A user entering the telehealth symptom wizard selects one or more symptom categories that best describe their concern. This helps triage the consultation and gives the doctor context before the call. Users with multiple related issues (e.g., cold symptoms + headache pain) can select multiple categories.
pros: Checkbox multi-select allows capturing co-occurring symptoms
Progress bar (1/3) sets clear expectations for wizard length
Large tap targets with visual feedback make mobile selection easy
Draft persistence means users can back out and return without losing data
cons: 6 categories may not cover all conditions—'Other' is a catch-all
No urgency triage question to filter out emergencies
Mental health as a checkbox may feel dismissive of serious conditions
No guidance on which category to choose for ambiguous symptoms
TH-002.impactIfWrong: If categories don't match user's condition, they may choose 'Other' and the doctor gets no useful pre-call context. Missing emergency triage could delay critical care.

TH-003.title: Symptoms Details (2/3)
assumptions: Symptom duration affects clinical decision-making
Users can accurately estimate how long they've had symptoms
1-10 pain scale is a familiar self-reporting mechanism
Duration buckets (<24h, 1-3d, 4-7d, >7d) are clinically meaningful
TH-003.userScenario: A user provides additional clinical context by indicating how long they've had symptoms and rating their discomfort level. This helps the doctor assess urgency and severity before the consultation. A user with a 2-day cold and mild discomfort (3/10) presents differently than one with week-long pain at 8/10.
pros: Radio buttons enforce single selection for duration (mutually exclusive)
Large slider with prominent number display makes pain rating intuitive
Mild/Severe labels anchor the pain scale for consistent interpretation
Duration options cover acute through chronic symptom timelines
cons: Pain scale is generic—not tailored to specific symptom categories from step 1
No option for intermittent symptoms (comes and goes)
Pain rating may not apply to all conditions (e.g., skin issues, mental health)
Duration doesn't capture whether symptoms are getting better or worse
TH-003.impactIfWrong: If duration/severity data is misinterpreted or irrelevant to the condition, doctor may over or under-estimate urgency. Users with non-pain symptoms may find the slider confusing.

TH-004.title: Symptoms Info (3/3)
assumptions: Free-text notes are valuable for context the wizard didn't capture
Photo uploads are optional but can help with visual conditions (rashes, injuries)
Users are willing to type additional details on mobile
Medical history and medications are stored elsewhere in profile
TH-004.userScenario: A user completes the symptom intake by adding free-form notes about anything the structured questions missed. For visible conditions like skin issues, they can indicate they've uploaded photos. A user with a rash might note 'appeared after hiking' or 'allergic to penicillin' to give the doctor critical context.
pros: Open text field captures edge cases the structured wizard missed
Photo checkbox signals readiness to share visual evidence
Full progress bar (3/3) confirms user is at the final intake step
Review button label prepares user for confirmation before booking
cons: Photo upload is a checkbox only—no actual upload UI implemented
No character limit or guidance on what to include in notes
Doesn't pull existing medical history from profile to pre-populate
No prompts for common important info (allergies, current medications)
TH-004.impactIfWrong: If users skip notes and photo upload isn't functional, doctors lose valuable diagnostic context. Missing allergy info could lead to unsafe prescriptions.

TH-005.title: Telehealth Review
assumptions: User needs to review all symptom data before committing to consultation
Consent checkbox is legally required before telehealth services
Insurance will cover telehealth consultations (GKV benefit)
User understands this is not for emergencies (119 consent language)
TH-005.userScenario: A user reviews their symptom intake summary and cost information before confirming the video consultation. They must acknowledge consent terms—particularly that this isn't for life-threatening emergencies—before proceeding. The edit button lets them fix any mistakes without starting over.
pros: Clear summary of symptoms, duration, and type before commitment
Edit button allows corrections without re-entering the full wizard
Cost transparency ('Covered by insurance') removes financial uncertainty
Emergency disclaimer protects both user and provider from misuse
cons: Consent checkbox is minimal—no link to full terms document
Insurance coverage assumes GKV—PKV users may have different cost rules
~15 min wait is still an estimate, may have changed since schedule screen
No option to add additional symptoms discovered while reviewing
TH-005.impactIfWrong: If consent language is insufficient, users may still try to use telehealth for emergencies. If cost display is wrong, PKV users could face unexpected bills.

TH-006.title: Confirmation
assumptions: User has completed symptom intake and consented to terms
Video appointment is created and stored in appointments list
Booking draft is cleared after successful confirmation
User can choose to wait immediately or be notified when their turn comes
TH-006.userScenario: A user sees confirmation that their consultation is scheduled and must decide: join the waiting room now, or leave and get a push notification when the doctor is ready. Users at home typically join immediately, while those on-the-go may prefer the notification option to continue other activities.
pros: Success animation provides satisfying visual feedback
Two clear options accommodate different user situations
Wait time estimate is repeated to reinforce expectations
Appointment is persisted so it appears in appointments list
cons: Notification option is UI-only—no actual push notification implemented
No cancel or reschedule option if user changes their mind
Wait time may have changed since they started the flow
No SMS/email confirmation sent with appointment details
TH-006.impactIfWrong: If notification option doesn't work, users who leave may miss their consultation window. If appointment isn't saved correctly, it won't appear in their history.

TH-007.title: Waiting Room
assumptions: User has confirmed their telehealth consultation and joined the queue
Camera and microphone access will be requested before the call
Queue position and wait time are meaningful to users
Auto-transition to video call when it's the user's turn (simulated at 4 seconds)
TH-007.userScenario: A user waits in a virtual queue while the doctor finishes with the previous patient. They can preview their camera feed to ensure lighting and framing are good, test their microphone, and see their queue position (e.g., 'Position: 2'). The animated wait indicator and tips help pass time productively.
pros: Camera preview lets users check their appearance before the call
Queue position + time estimate reduces uncertainty about the wait
Test buttons for camera/mic help troubleshoot AV issues early
Tip card provides useful guidance for better consultation quality
cons: Queue position is hardcoded—not connected to real queue system
Camera preview is a static placeholder, not actual camera feed
Leave waiting room option is just a link—no confirmation dialog
4-second auto-transition is too fast to read the screen in demo
TH-007.impactIfWrong: If queue data is inaccurate, users may leave thinking they have time and miss their turn. If AV test doesn't work, users discover issues only when the call starts.

TH-008.title: Video Call
assumptions: WebRTC or equivalent video infrastructure is provided by Teleclinic
User has granted camera and microphone permissions
Call duration tracking helps users and doctors manage consultation length
Standard video call controls (mute, camera off, end call) are expected
TH-008.userScenario: A user is in an active video consultation with a doctor. They can see the doctor's video feed (or avatar), a picture-in-picture preview of themselves, and the call duration. Standard controls let them mute/unmute, toggle camera, or end the call. The dark UI minimizes distraction during the medical conversation.
pros: Full-screen doctor view with PIP self-view follows video call conventions
Running timer helps both parties track consultation length
Toggle states (mic/cam on/off) are visually distinct
Red end-call button is prominent and hard to hit accidentally
cons: No actual video feed—just placeholder UI for demo purposes
Chat button exists but no text chat functionality implemented
No network quality indicator or reconnection handling shown
Ending call immediately transitions to summary—no 'are you sure?' prompt
TH-008.impactIfWrong: If video infrastructure fails, users see a blank screen and lose their consultation. If controls don't work, users may be unable to hear/see the doctor.

TH-009.title: Telehealth Summary
assumptions: Consultation has ended and the video appointment is marked complete
Doctor's diagnosis and recommendations are available post-call
Users value the ability to rate their experience
Follow-up booking is a common next action after consultations
TH-009.userScenario: A user reviews the summary of their completed consultation, including the doctor's diagnosis (e.g., 'Common cold') and treatment recommendations. They can rate the experience with a 5-star system and optionally book a follow-up appointment. This screen serves as both closure and a gateway to continued care.
pros: Clear summary of diagnosis and recommendations for future reference
Star rating system is familiar and quick to complete
Follow-up booking CTA is contextually relevant right after consultation
Appointment marked as completed in storage for history tracking
cons: Diagnosis/recommendations are hardcoded demo data, not from actual doctor
No way to download or share the consultation summary
No link to any prescriptions that may have been issued during the call
Rating isn't submitted anywhere—just local state for demo
TH-009.impactIfWrong: If summary data doesn't match what the doctor actually said, users may follow incorrect advice. If rating system is broken, user feedback is lost.

TH-010.title: Teleclinic Simulated
assumptions: Teleclinic is a real third-party telehealth provider with their own booking flow
Deep linking or WebView integration passes the user to Teleclinic's interface
User's symptoms from the app flow should pre-populate consultation reason
Appointment booked in Teleclinic must sync back to the app's appointments list
TH-010.userScenario: A user who chose 'Pick a Time' on the schedule screen is redirected to Teleclinic's booking interface. The simulated browser chrome (URL bar, nav buttons) shows this is an external partner experience. Users select a consultation reason and available time slot, then book. The confirmed appointment syncs back to the app's appointments list.
pros: Browser chrome UI signals this is a partner handoff, not native app
Dynamic time slots based on current time feel realistic
Symptoms from prior wizard pre-populate the reason list
Appointment is saved to local storage, appearing in appointments list
cons: Simulated UI doesn't match real Teleclinic branding or flow
No actual OAuth or session handoff—user context isn't really shared
Cancel returns to booking/type, not a proper back navigation
Loading state is artificial delay, not real API communication
TH-010.impactIfWrong: If real Teleclinic integration differs significantly, users will be confused by the transition. If appointment sync fails, users won't see their booking in the app.

PHR-001.title: Pharmacy Map
assumptions: User has location services enabled or has provided a default location
Pharmacy data includes coordinates for map pin placement
Users prefer visual spatial context when choosing a pharmacy
Bottom sheet preview reduces need to tap into full list
PHR-001.userScenario: A user with an e-prescription needs to find a nearby pharmacy to pick it up. They open the pharmacy finder expecting a map-centric view that shows locations relative to their position. Users typically scan pins visually to find the closest option, then tap for details.
pros: Map-first design matches mental model of 'finding nearby'
Pulsing user location indicator provides spatial orientation
Bottom sheet preview shows nearest pharmacy without extra tap
Search bar filters map pins in real-time
cons: Fake map pattern (dots) doesn't show real streets or landmarks
No actual GPS integration—location is simulated
Pin positions are hardcoded, not derived from real coordinates
Can't drag/zoom the map to explore further areas
PHR-001.impactIfWrong: If users expect real map functionality, the static dots pattern may confuse them. Without actual location services, the 'nearby' concept loses meaning.

PHR-002.title: Pharmacy List
assumptions: Some users prefer scanning a list over interpreting a map
Filters like 'Open Now' and '24 Hours' are high-priority for prescription pickup
Distance data is available and meaningful for sorting
Pharmacy data includes ratings and reviews
PHR-002.userScenario: A user who knows roughly what they need (e.g., a pharmacy open late or one with delivery) wants to quickly scan options and filter. List view suits users who are comparison-shopping rather than purely proximity-driven. They may filter by 'Open Now' if it's evening or '24 Hours' for emergencies.
pros: Filter chips enable quick narrowing without leaving the view
Each card shows key decision factors: name, distance, status, rating
Staggered animation adds polish without slowing interaction
Empty state guides users to adjust filters rather than showing nothing
cons: Distance values are static—not recalculated from user's actual location
Delivery filter exists but no delivery flow is implemented
No way to combine map and list views simultaneously
Rating data is mock—no real review aggregation
PHR-002.impactIfWrong: If filters suggest functionality that doesn't exist (like delivery), users may be disappointed. Static distance values could send users to a pharmacy that isn't actually closest.

PHR-003.title: Pharmacy Detail
assumptions: Users need full hours and contact info before visiting
'Reserve Prescription' creates a local record the user can reference
Users may need directions or want to call ahead
E-prescription redemption requires presenting Gesundheitskarte at counter
PHR-003.userScenario: A user has selected a pharmacy and wants to confirm it meets their needs before traveling. They check hours to ensure it's open, review the address, and may reserve their prescription so the pharmacy can prepare it. Some users call ahead to confirm stock availability.
pros: Comprehensive info card layout covers address, hours, and contact
Reserve Prescription action gives user sense of commitment
Get Directions and Call buttons reduce friction for next steps
Info note reminds users of Gesundheitskarte requirement upfront
cons: Reserve Prescription only saves locally—no actual pharmacy notification
Get Directions doesn't open maps app (no deep link)
Call button doesn't initiate phone call (no tel: link)
No stock availability or prescription fulfillment time estimate
PHR-003.impactIfWrong: If users believe 'Reserve Prescription' notifies the pharmacy, they may arrive expecting their order to be ready. Non-functional direction and call buttons break expected mobile patterns.

APT-001.title: Appointments List
assumptions: Users want a single view for all upcoming appointments
Smart Match bookings need a 'processing' state while awaiting doctor confirmation
Filter by appointment type (in-person vs video) is a common need
Push notifications for booking confirmation improve engagement
APT-001.userScenario: A user opens the app to check their upcoming appointments. They may have booked via Smart Match (still awaiting confirmation) or directly. The list shows all scheduled visits in one place, letting users quickly see what's coming up and tap into details for any appointment.
pros: Processing state with animation clearly signals pending Smart Match confirmation
Filter chips let users focus on specific appointment types
Loading skeletons prevent layout shift while data loads
FAB provides quick access to new booking flow
cons: Smart Match webhook simulation (5s delay) is hardcoded, not real-time
No real push notification system—just in-app banner simulation
Doctor assignment is random, not based on actual availability
Past appointments moved to separate History tab—users must navigate away
APT-001.impactIfWrong: If processing state lingers without resolution, users may think the app is broken. Simulated push notifications may set expectations for system-level alerts that don't exist.

APT-002.title: Appointment Detail
assumptions: Users need to review appointment details before attending
Cancellation requires confirmation to prevent accidental taps
Reschedule links back to calendar flow rather than inline editing
Directions link to external maps app via Google Maps URL
APT-002.userScenario: A user taps an appointment from the list to see full details—doctor info, clinic address, date/time, and what to bring. They may add it to their device calendar, get directions, reschedule for a better time, or cancel if their situation changed.
pros: Summary card consolidates doctor, location, and timing in scannable layout
'What to Bring' checklist reduces pre-visit anxiety
Cancel confirmation dialog prevents accidental cancellations
Get Directions opens Google Maps with clinic query
cons: Clinic address is hardcoded (Friedrichstraße 123)—not pulled from appointment data
Rating is static (4.8)—not connected to real reviews
'Add to Calendar' shows toast but doesn't create actual calendar event
Reschedule redirects to generic calendar, not pre-filled with current appointment
APT-002.impactIfWrong: Hardcoded addresses could send users to wrong locations. Non-functional calendar integration may frustrate users who rely on reminders.

HIST-001.title: History
assumptions: Past appointments should be separate from upcoming to reduce list clutter
Grouping by month helps users locate specific visits
Search across doctor, specialty, and clinic covers common lookup patterns
Cancelled appointments are still valuable to show (e.g., for rebooking)
HIST-001.userScenario: A user wants to recall a past appointment—perhaps to rebook with the same doctor, reference a diagnosis date, or check which specialist they saw. They scroll through month-grouped history or use search to find the specific visit.
pros: Month grouping creates natural timeline structure
Search covers doctor name, specialty, and clinic
Visual distinction between completed (green) and cancelled (red) status
Cards link to detail view for full appointment info
cons: €0.00 amount shown on all cards—no real cost tracking
No export or download of appointment history
No prescription or diagnosis info shown in history cards
Clicking cancelled appointments shows same detail screen as completed ones
HIST-001.impactIfWrong: If users expect cost tracking or medical records from history, the prototype will underwhelm. Lack of differentiation between cancelled and completed detail views may confuse users.

PRF-001.title: Profile
assumptions: Users need a central hub to access all account-related settings
Profile data (name, email) loads from localStorage after brief delay
Insurance type (GKV vs PKV) determines which insurance detail page to navigate to
Logout requires confirmation to prevent accidental sign-outs
PRF-001.userScenario: A user opens their profile to manage account settings, update insurance information, or change app preferences. The screen serves as a navigation hub with grouped menu items for Account, Support, and Legal sections, plus a prominent sign-out option.
pros: Grouped menu sections (Account, Support) reduce cognitive load
Avatar and name at top creates personal connection to the app
Logout confirmation dialog prevents accidental sign-outs
Language preference shown inline with current selection
cons: Notifications menu item shows 'Coming soon' toast—no real notification settings
Insurance routing logic depends on localStorage type which may be unset
No account deletion option—users must contact support
Linked accounts count is hardcoded to '1 connected'
PRF-001.impactIfWrong: If insurance type is missing or corrupted, users may be routed to the wrong insurance page (GKV vs PKV), causing confusion about their coverage settings.

PRF-002.title: Edit Profile
assumptions: Most profile fields are managed by partner SSO (dm) and cannot be edited directly
Only phone number is user-editable in this prototype
Date of birth changes require support contact for identity verification
Unsaved changes should trigger a confirmation dialog before leaving
PRF-002.userScenario: A user wants to update their contact information. They discover most fields (name, email, address) are locked because they're managed by their dm account. Only the phone number can be edited directly, with validation ensuring German format (+49).
pros: Lock icons clearly indicate which fields are managed externally
'Managed by dm' links explain why fields are read-only
Dirty state tracking prevents accidental data loss
Phone validation ensures consistent German number format
cons: Most fields locked creates frustration if user needs to fix a typo
No inline explanation of WHY external management exists
Address shows 'No address on file' if empty—no way to add one
'Managed by dm' links don't actually navigate anywhere
PRF-002.impactIfWrong: If phone validation is too strict, users with valid numbers may be unable to save. If too lenient, appointment confirmation SMS could fail to deliver.

PRF-003.title: Linked Accounts
assumptions: Users may have accounts with retail partners (dm, PAYBACK) or their insurance provider
Linking accounts enables faster SSO login and benefit syncing
Connection state persists in localStorage across sessions
dm is pre-connected by default since it's the primary SSO partner
PRF-003.userScenario: A user wants to connect their PAYBACK account to earn points on health bookings. They see which accounts are already connected (dm by default), can unlink existing connections, and connect new partners with a single tap.
pros: Clear separation between 'Connected' and 'Available' sections
Unlink action is prominent and requires no confirmation (easy to reverse)
Brief descriptions explain the benefit of each connection
Instant feedback via toast messages on connect/unlink
cons: No actual OAuth flow—toggling just flips a boolean in localStorage
Connection date is hardcoded to 'January 15, 2026'
Insurance provider label pulled from saved data may be stale
No confirmation before unlinking an account
PRF-003.impactIfWrong: If linked account state doesn't persist correctly, users may lose SSO access or miss PAYBACK points on future bookings.

PRF-004.title: Insurance Info GKV
assumptions: User has statutory public health insurance (GKV)
Insurance type (GKV) cannot be changed without support intervention
Insurance number follows German format: 1 letter + 9 digits
Rescan Health Card button would trigger NFC in production
PRF-004.userScenario: A GKV-insured user needs to update their insurance provider after switching jobs. They can select from major German public insurers (TK, AOK, Barmer, DAK, IKK) and update their insurance number. The insurance type badge is locked to prevent accidental changes.
pros: Blue badge with lock icon clearly indicates GKV type is protected
Dropdown includes the most common German public insurers
Insurance number format hint (A123456789) guides correct entry
'Rescan Health Card' suggests NFC capability for future use
cons: Limited to 5 insurers—users with other providers must contact support
'Rescan Health Card' button has no actual functionality
No validation that insurance number matches selected provider
Type change requires support contact—friction for users who switch to PKV
