PRF-005.title: Insurance Info PKV
assumptions: User has private health insurance (PKV)
PKV users authenticate prescriptions via GesundheitsID (not NFC card)
GesundheitsID setup status is stored in app settings
Insurance type cannot be changed without support intervention
PRF-005.userScenario: A PKV-insured user checks whether their GesundheitsID is connected for prescription access. They can see their current private insurer (Allianz, DKV, Debeka, AXA, HUK-COBURG), update it, and toggle GesundheitsID connection status.
pros: Purple badge visually distinguishes PKV from GKV (blue) screens
GesundheitsID status banner clearly shows connected vs not-set-up state
Toggle allows simulating connect/disconnect for demo purposes
Separate screen from GKV prevents confusion between insurance types
cons: GesundheitsID 'setup' is just a boolean toggle—no actual ID verification
'Setup GesundheitsID in App' doesn't navigate to real setup flow
Limited to 5 private insurers—niche providers not listed
No policy number field—only provider selection
PRF-005.impactIfWrong: If GesundheitsID status doesn't match reality, users may attempt prescription redemption and fail authentication at the pharmacy or doctor's office.

PRF-006.title: Language Selection
assumptions: App supports two languages: English (en) and German (de)
Language preference persists via i18next and localStorage
UI updates immediately upon language selection
German healthcare context means most users prefer German
PRF-006.userScenario: A user who prefers English wants to switch the app from German. They see the current language with a green checkmark, then select from available options. The app immediately reloads content in the chosen language and returns to profile.
pros: Current language shown at top with green checkmark for quick confirmation
Radio button UI makes selection state unambiguous
Helper text explains that the setting affects all app content
Auto-navigate back to profile after selection reduces taps
cons: Only 2 languages—no support for Turkish or other common German immigrant languages
200ms delay before navigation may feel sluggish
No preview of how content looks in selected language
Some medical terms may not translate well to English
PRF-006.impactIfWrong: If language setting doesn't persist correctly, users may see the app revert to German on next launch, forcing repeated language changes.

PRF-007.title: Help & Support
assumptions: Users need self-service help before contacting support
FAQ, Contact Support, and Report Problem are the primary support actions
Static pages exist for FAQ and support contact forms
Support channels are available during German business hours
PRF-007.userScenario: A user encounters an issue with their prescription redemption and needs help. They open Help & Support to find FAQ articles, contact support directly, or report a bug. Each option navigates to a dedicated static page.
pros: Three clear options cover most support scenarios
Consistent menu row design matches profile hub for familiarity
Icons provide quick visual scanning (question, chat, flag)
Simple navigation—no nested menus to confuse users
cons: FAQ and Report Problem both navigate to static pages—no in-app chat
No search function to quickly find relevant help articles
No ticket tracking for submitted support requests
Report Problem and Contact Support go to same destination
PRF-007.impactIfWrong: If support pages are unreachable or unhelpful, users with urgent issues (failed prescriptions, missed appointments) have no recourse within the app.

PRF-008.title: Privacy & Legal
assumptions: German healthcare apps require GDPR-compliant privacy policies
Legal disclosure (Impressum) is mandatory under German law
Terms of Service must be accessible for user reference
Static legal pages exist and are kept up-to-date
PRF-008.userScenario: A user wants to review how their health data is handled before connecting their GesundheitsID. They access Privacy Policy, Legal Disclosure, and Terms of Service from a single hub to understand their rights and the app's obligations.
pros: Three essential legal documents accessible from one screen
Consistent menu design with profile hub for familiarity
Clear icons distinguish each document type
Simple navigation without nested complexity
cons: Legal Disclosure and Terms of Service navigate to the same static page
No version history or 'last updated' indicator for legal documents
No in-app summary—users must read full legal text
No way to export or share legal documents
PRF-008.impactIfWrong: If legal pages are missing or outdated, the app may violate German Telemediengesetz requirements, exposing the operator to regulatory penalties.

SSO-001.title: SSO Loading
assumptions: User initiated login via a retail partner (dm, PAYBACK) button
SSO handoff takes 2+ seconds for OAuth token exchange
Partner logo (dm) should be displayed to reassure user of correct flow
Network errors should show retry option rather than silent failure
SSO-001.userScenario: A user tapped 'Sign in with dm' on the login screen. They see a loading state with the dm logo while the app exchanges OAuth tokens with the partner. After success, they proceed to complete their profile with additional required fields.
pros: Partner logo reinforces user is in the correct SSO flow
Spinner provides visual feedback that something is happening
Error state offers retry and fallback to regular login
Auto-marks dm as linked account upon successful auth
cons: 2-second delay is hardcoded—no actual OAuth exchange happening
Error state exists but is never triggered in prototype
No timeout handling if partner auth takes too long
Only dm partner supported—PAYBACK would need separate implementation
SSO-001.impactIfWrong: If SSO fails silently without error state, users may think the app is frozen and force-quit, losing trust in the partner login flow.

SSO-002.title: Complete Profile
assumptions: SSO provides name and email but not phone, DOB, or insurance
User must provide missing fields before accessing app features
Phone number is required for appointment reminders
Insurance type determines prescription redemption flow later
SSO-002.userScenario: After SSO authentication, a user sees their name and email pre-filled (locked) from dm. They complete the remaining required fields—phone number, date of birth, and optionally insurance provider—before being granted full app access.
pros: Read-only SSO fields with lock icons show data source clearly
'From your dm account' section separates partner data from user input
Insurance selection sets up correct GKV/PKV flow for prescriptions
Single 'Continue' button reduces decision paralysis
cons: SSO data is hardcoded (Max Mustermann)—no real partner integration
No validation on phone or DOB fields before submission
Insurance field is optional but needed for key features
Address not collected—may be needed for prescription delivery
SSO-002.impactIfWrong: If insurance type is not set during SSO onboarding, users may encounter unexpected flows when trying to redeem prescriptions, causing confusion about GKV vs PKV processes.

STATIC-001.title: FAQ
assumptions: Users prefer self-service help before contacting support
Most questions fall into Appointments, Prescriptions, or Video categories
Accordion UI reduces visual overwhelm for long FAQ lists
Search helps users find relevant answers quickly
STATIC-001.userScenario: A user has a question about how e-prescriptions work before redeeming their first one. They open the FAQ, optionally search for 'prescription', and expand the relevant accordion item to read a concise answer. If unsatisfied, they can tap through to contact support.
pros: Grouped sections (Appointments, Prescriptions, Video) organize content logically
Accordion collapse keeps the page scannable
Search bar at top enables quick filtering
'Contact Support' link at bottom catches users who don't find their answer
cons: Search input is present but not wired to filter functionality
Static content—no CMS or backend to update FAQs easily
Limited to 8 questions—doesn't cover edge cases
No analytics to track which questions are most viewed
STATIC-001.impactIfWrong: If FAQ content is outdated or incomplete, users may follow incorrect instructions (e.g., old prescription flow), leading to failed transactions and support tickets.

STATIC-002.title: Support
assumptions: Users need multiple contact channels (phone, email, form)
Support hours are German business hours (Mon-Fri 8-6)
Subject categorization helps route tickets to correct team
Toast confirmation reassures user their message was received
STATIC-002.userScenario: A user encountered a technical issue with video consultation and needs to report it. They see support contact details (phone, email, hours), then fill out a message form selecting 'Technical Issue' as the subject. After submission, they receive a toast confirmation.
pros: Contact card at top provides immediate phone/email options
Business hours set expectations for response time
Subject dropdown helps categorize and route support requests
Quick links to FAQ and Bug Report offer alternative paths
cons: Form submission shows toast but doesn't actually send anything
No ticket number or email confirmation for tracking
'Report a Bug' button has no destination—just sits there
No live chat option for urgent issues
STATIC-002.impactIfWrong: If users believe their support message was sent but it wasn't, they may wait days for a response that never comes, eroding trust in the app's reliability.

STATIC-003.title: Privacy Policy
assumptions: GDPR compliance requires clear disclosure of data collection and usage
Health data processing needs explicit explanation due to sensitivity
Users should understand their rights (access, rectification, erasure)
Long legal text benefits from 'back to top' navigation
STATIC-003.userScenario: A user wants to understand how their health data is handled before connecting GesundheitsID. They scroll through sections covering data collection, usage, sharing with partners (Teleclinic, pharmacies), and their GDPR rights. A floating button helps them return to the top.
pros: Clear section headings (Data We Collect, How We Use, etc.) aid scanning
Bulleted lists make dense legal content more digestible
Floating 'back to top' button appears on scroll for long content
'Last Updated' date shows policy currency
cons: Static content—no mechanism for users to accept/decline specific uses
No version history or change log for returning users
Contact email (privacy@medalpha.de) may not be monitored
No PDF download option for offline reference
STATIC-003.impactIfWrong: If privacy policy doesn't accurately reflect data practices, the app may violate GDPR Article 13 disclosure requirements, exposing the operator to regulatory fines.

STATIC-004.title: Legal Disclosure
assumptions: German Telemediengesetz (TMG) requires Impressum on all commercial apps
Company registration details (HRB, VAT) must be publicly accessible
Managing directors must be named for legal accountability
DiGA and MPG compliance notes relevant for healthcare app credibility
STATIC-004.userScenario: A user or regulator wants to verify the legal entity behind the app. They view the Impressum showing company name (MedAlpha GmbH), address, commercial register details, VAT ID, managing directors, and contact information. A regulatory note confirms DiGA/MPG compliance.
pros: All mandatory Impressum fields present (company, address, register, VAT, directors)
Contact section with email and phone enables direct communication
Regulatory note signals healthcare compliance credibility
Clean card-based layout organizes dense legal information
cons: Company details are fictional (MedAlpha GmbH, Musterstraße)—placeholder for prototype
Email links may not be functional in prototype
No downloadable PDF version for official records
No update date to indicate currency of information
STATIC-004.impactIfWrong: Missing or incorrect Impressum violates §5 TMG and can result in warnings (Abmahnungen) and fines from competitors or consumer protection agencies.

ERR-001.title: 404 Not Found
assumptions: Users may navigate to invalid routes via deep links or bookmarks
Error page should clearly indicate what went wrong
Developer hint ('forgot to add to router?') aids debugging during development
Minimal styling acceptable for error states
ERR-001.userScenario: A user follows an outdated bookmark or mistyped URL and lands on a page that doesn't exist. They see a clear '404 Page Not Found' message with an error icon, indicating the requested page isn't available.
pros: Clear error icon and heading communicate the problem immediately
Developer-friendly message helps identify missing routes during development
Minimal, centered layout focuses attention on the error
Consistent card styling matches app design system
cons: No navigation back to home or other app sections
Developer message ('forgot to add to router?') inappropriate for production
No search or suggestions for what user might have been looking for
Doesn't follow mobile-first 375px constraint of rest of app
ERR-001.impactIfWrong: If 404 page offers no escape route, users may abandon the app entirely rather than manually navigating to a known valid URL.
